pr_title: Add step to check secure protocols supported by server

+/*

+
+package org.vividus.bdd.steps;
+
+import java.util.List;
+import java.util.stream.Collectors;
+
+import org.hamcrest.Matcher;
+import org.hamcrest.Matchers;
+
+public enum ListComparisonRule
+{
+    CONTAIN
+    {
+        @SuppressWarnings({ "unchecked", "rawtypes" })
+        @Override
+        public <T> Matcher<Iterable<T>> getComparisonRule(List<T> values)
+        {
+            return values.stream()
+                         .map(Matchers::hasItem)
+                         .collect(Collectors.collectingAndThen(Collectors.toList(),
+                             m -> Matchers.allOf((List) m)));

timeline.message: Add step to check secure protocols supported by server

timeline.bodyText:
let's group comparison rules:
* xref:comparison-rule.adoc[Comparison Rule]
* xref:collection-comparison-rule.adoc[Collection Comparison Rule]
* xref:variable-scope.adoc[Variable Scope]
timeline.author: valfirst
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1,3 +1,4 @@
 .Parameter types
 * xref:comparison-rule.adoc[Comparison Rule]
 * xref:variable-scope.adoc[Variable Scope]
+* xref:collection-comparison-rule.adoc[Collection Comparison Rule]

timeline.bodyText: why do you need allOf here?
timeline.author: valfirst

replies.bodyText: containsInAnyOrder returns Iterable<? extends T> while hasItems returns Iterable, so I use allOf to "align"  types
replies.author: uarlouski

replies.bodyText: public <T> Matcher<Iterable<? extends T>> getComparisonRule(List<T> items) ?
replies.author: valfirst

replies.bodyText: Github hidden type param for hasItems, that's Iterable < T >
replies.author: uarlouski

timeline.bodyText:
From my point of view, it is easier to read using a data source
CONTAIN, List.of(1, 0), List.of(1, 1, 1), false
where
rule, expected, actual, comparisonResult
